content: The Act titled "District of Columbia Building Heights Act of 1994" limits the height of buildings in the District of Columbia. The Act limits building height in the District of Columbia based on street width and restricts the size and height of roof structures not used for human occupancy. Roof structures not used for human occupancy may be built taller than usual with approval from the Mayor of the District of Columbia, as long as they are fireproof and set back from the building's walls. The Mayor cannot waive this requirement. The height of roof structures not used for human occupancy must be approved by the Mayor of the District of Columbia, ensuring they are fireproof and set back from the building's walls. The Mayor cannot waive this requirement unless it is unduly restrictive or highly impractical, and does not interfere with the purpose of the Act or affect adjacent buildings' exposure to light and air. An 'exterior or bounding wall' is defined as any wall over 4 feet in height or depth exposed to the outside. The Act increases penalties for violations, changing the fine from $10-$100 per day to a maximum of $10,000 per day. The definition of 'exterior or bounding wall' and 'roof' is clarified, with specific criteria outlined for each. The Act increases penalties for violations, with fines now up to $10,000 per day. SEC. 3. INCREASE IN AUTHORITY OF NATIONAL CAPITAL PLANNING COMMISSION TO ENFORCE BUILDING HEIGHT LIMITATIONS. Requiring NCPC Approval for Roof Structures Exceeding General Limitations, the Act is amended to include the National Capital Planning Commission in addition to the Mayor of the District of Columbia for approval of building heights. The Act "An Act providing for a comprehensive development of the park and playground system of the National Capital" is amended to include the National Capital Planning Commission for approval of building heights, specifically roof structures, within 45 days of submission. The Act allows the National Capital Planning Commission to approve building heights in the District of Columbia within 45 days of submission. Additionally, the Commission or its members can request approval for the height of any building proposed in the District. The Act allows the National Capital Planning Commission and its members to enforce building height limitations in the District of Columbia. The Act also amends Section 8 of the building heights act to include the Commission or its members in enforcing limitations. The National Capital Planning Commission and its members have the authority to enforce building height limitations in the District of Columbia, with members able to do so at their own expense unless authorized by the Commission. The Act also includes a conforming amendment to Section 11 of the Act of June 20, 1938. Section 11 of the Act of June 20, 1938 is amended to clarify that the National Capital Planning Commission and its members have the authority to enforce building limitations in the District of Columbia. The amendments made by this Act will apply to buildings and structures in the District of Columbia for which building permits are issued on or after March 23, 1994.
